moves.1. e4:
Hi everyone!

Here is an unrated game as black against my buddy Michael which finished today.  Sadly I ended up copping Old Matey.  Before that, however, Glenda played a game of Chase Me Charlie with Michael's king who unfortunately found a safe niche in my position and I ran out of checks.  I lost the game due to failure to develop Fou Leblanc in a timely manner.  When Fou Leblanc eventually came out on MOVE THIRTY, he met an inglorious death to the white rook.  The end came 3 moves later.  Anyway, on with the show.  We have a double king pawn opening with e4 and e5.
moves.1... e5 2. f4: 2. f4 - and Michael gives me the King's Gambit which I accept.
moves.2... exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5: 5. Ne5 - this bold move to e5 by white's steed is called the Kiezeritzky Gambit.  The knight sometimes goes to g5 which is called the Allgaier Gambit in which a knight is sacrificed for a pawn on f7.  The black king must capture to avoid dropping a rook and he becomes mighty exposed, but this is the calmer, saner Kiezeritzky and I respond with a sane developing move such as Nf6.
moves.5... Nf6 6. Bc4 d5: 6. ........ d5 - opening a line for Fou Leblanc.  You would never believe that he stays at home until the game is 30 moves old but he does.
moves.7. exd5 Bd6 8. d4 O-O: 8. ....... 0-0 - Henry goes kingside but this is rather open.
moves.12. Kf1 Qf6 13. Qd2 Bxe5: 13. ........ Bxe5 - after white quietly moves the Wicked Witch of the West out to d2 there is a series of trades.  First up, a piece trade.
moves.14. dxe5 Rxe5: 14. ....... Rxe5 - now a pawn trade.  The BR cannot be captured because the f4 pawn is pinned.
moves.16. Kg2 Qh6: 16. ........ Qh6 - Glenda eyes a chance to attack down the g or h file so she moves to h6 still keeping the f pawn in a pin, this time against the Witch.
moves.18... Nf6: 18. ....... Nf6 - clearing the way for Fou Leblanc but Michael has other ideas.
moves.19. d6: 19. d6! - good move, I do not want to lose a pawn so I take on d6.
moves.20... Kg7 21. Re7 Qxh4: 21. .......... Qxh4 - this pawn turns out to be poisoned but although I did anticipate white's next moves I thought that I would be able to get a perpetual somehow.
moves.22. Rxf7+ Kg6 23. Ne4 Qh3+: 23. ........ Qh3+ - here is a series of checks where the WK is chased around the board.
moves.24. Kg1 Qe3+ 25. Kf1 Qh3+ 26. Ke1: 26. Ke1 - the WK moves towards the centre.
moves.28... Qf3+ 29. Kb4 a5+: 29. ........ a5+ - a humble footman steps in to try and help Glenda but ......
moves.30. Kb5: 30. Kb5 - ....... The WK ensures I have only one check left, will it work?
moves.30... Bd7+ 31. Rxd7: 31. Rxd7 - Glenda took the knight on e4 but just as I was about to hit the submit button I noticed that white's lsb could pin her against Henry on d3.  So I hit reset and I decide on Ra6 to attack the witch and cover black's third rank.
moves.31... Ra6 32. Qe7 Nxd7: 32. ....... Nxd7 - I decide to take the rook as my knight is not pinned, however the rook is poisoned because next move I cop Old Matey with the Wicked Witch landing on g5.  Sigh and double sigh.  My only consolation was that the game was unrated.  Hope you have had a good read.  Bye for now.  Joanne

gameName: My king chase hits the buffers!
